content: The "Fair Trade Accessibility and Accountability Act of 2017" allows small firms to receive assistance in filing petitions for investigations under the Tariff Act of 1930. The "Fair Trade Accessibility and Accountability Act of 2017" authorizes the Secretary of Commerce to provide financial assistance to small firms for filing petitions seeking remedies under the Tariff Act of 1930. The "Fair Trade Accessibility and Accountability Act of 2017" allows the Secretary of Commerce to offer financial aid to small firms for filing petitions under the Tariff Act of 1930. The Secretary evaluates applications based on the firm's ability-to-pay and local economic impact. Assistance to small firms cannot exceed 75 percent of filing costs. The "Fair Trade Accessibility and Accountability Act of 2017" allows the Secretary of Commerce to provide financial aid to small firms for filing petitions under the Tariff Act of 1930. Assistance covers 75% of filing costs and includes costs related to preliminary and final determinations. Definitions include "administering authority" and "small firm" criteria. SEC. 3. Modification of industry support for petition determinations under countervailing duty investigations and antidumping duty investigations under the Tariff Act of 1930. Modification of industry support for petition determinations under countervailing duty and antidumping duty investigations in the Tariff Act of 1930, including changes to percentage thresholds and clause removals. The amendments made by this section modify industry support for petition determinations under countervailing duty and antidumping duty investigations in the Tariff Act of 1930, including changes to percentage thresholds and clause removals. The effective date for these amendments is the date of enactment of the Act, applying to investigations initiated 90 days after enactment. SEC. 4. AUTHORITY OF ITC TO ISSUE TRADE ENFORCEMENT ADVISORY OPINIONS. Section 332 of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to allow US businesses to petition congressional committees to determine if a foreign country has violated trade agreements regarding goods or services. The committees will review the petition and refer it for further action if agreed upon. The Commission will review petitions referred by congressional committees to determine if a violation occurred, allowing for comments from the foreign government and stakeholders. An advisory opinion will be issued within 120 days regarding the basis for the violation. The Commission will review petitions referred by congressional committees to determine if a violation occurred, allowing for comments from the foreign government and stakeholders. An advisory opinion will be issued within 120 days regarding the basis for the violation. The Commission shall make available to the public all materials submitted relating to the petition, including definitions for terms like 'appropriate congressional committees,' 'Commission,' and 'United States business enterprise.' Entities organized under US laws or foreign branches of such entities are subject to review for potential violations by the Commission. The sense of Congress is that China should remain a nonmarket economy country until it meets criteria for market economy status. The President should enforce antidumping and countervailing duty laws against China and other nonmarket economy countries until they meet the criteria. SEC. 6. MADE IN AMERICA GSA SCHEDULE. SEC. 6. MADE IN AMERICA GSA SCHEDULE. Any good on a Federal supply schedule must be made in America, with all or virtually all parts made in the United States. The Administrator of General Services enforces this using the Made in USA Standard by the Federal Trade Commission. Noncompliance results in penalties for suppliers. The supplier of any good not in compliance with the Made in USA Standard faces penalties: $100,000 for first offense, $300,000 for subsequent offenses, and permanent debarment from Federal supply schedules. The Administrator of General Services will establish a tip line within 90 days for reporting violations. Services will establish a tip line for reporting violations of subsection (a), with individuals receiving 75 percent of fines if their tip leads to a violation discovery. The Administrator of General Services must notify suppliers of the requirements within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This section will take effect 90 days after the Act's enactment, except for specific provisions. The Act will apply to contracts entered into after its enactment, specifically those related to posting goods on a Federal supply schedule.
